messages.subject: Re: Soten & Namban
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Curran, Yes, that is were I saw the combination of names which led to some of my confusion. I re-visited Aoi-Art and like what I see but their confusion
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Curran,
Yes, that is were I saw the combination of names which led to some of
my confusion. I re-visited Aoi-Art and like what I see but their
confusion with names bothers me.
Elliott

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Soten & Namban
messages.msgSnippet: Elliott, Namban  Nanban ~if your question about Namban related to Soten stems from Aoi Arts posting last night of a Soten tsuba and them stating it is
messages.messageBody:
Elliott,

Namban <=> Nanban

~if your question about Namban related to Soten stems
from Aoi Arts' posting last night of a "Soten" tsuba
and them stating it is Namban, please know that it is
just a mistake by the Aoi Arts people.


Curran

messages.subject: Re: Soten & Namban
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you Dr. John, I now need to add another name to my confusion or curiosity.... Nanban tsuba. We have no comparison between Soten and Namban, is Nanban
messages.messageBody:
Thank you Dr. John,
I now need to add another name to my confusion or curiosity....
Nanban tsuba.
We have no comparison between Soten and Namban, is Nanban tsuba
related in some way to either Namban or Soten? It seems somewhere I
read about a Nanban tsuba signed Mogarashi Soten. Are these schools
related? I can see some likenesses between Nanban and Soten.
As always, thank you and the group for my continuing education.
Elliott

messages.subject: Re: Soten & Namban
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Elliot I know of no relationship whatsoever between the Namban and the Soten groups of tsuba.  The only feature that may be considered common to them both
messages.messageBody:
Dear Elliot

I know of no relationship whatsoever between the Namban and the Soten
groups of tsuba. The only feature that may be considered common to
them both is some evidence of a Chinese influence. However, while
with Namban tsuba this resulted in a completely novel metalworking
technique, Soten tsuba use conventional, Japanese techniques to
illustrate historical sujects which may be of Chinese derivation.
But there a lots of differences:-

Soten tsuba came initially from a recognised 'school' of makers,
although they were later mass produced outside this. There was never
a recognised Namban 'school', the namban influence being ubiquitous.

Namban tsuba had their origin in China, were imported into Japan at
the end of the C16, and reached the peak of their popularity in the
late C18. Soten tsuba date from the early C18 and continued to be
made, as poor quality shiiremono, into the late Edo period.
(Although I have no evidence for this, I suspect that many of the
latter may also have been produced using the 'lost wax' method of
casting.)

True examples of the Namban group are characterised by extensive
openwork and undercutting, whereas with Soten tsuba, while they may
demonstrate some degree of openwork, this is not a constant feature
and never includes undercutting.

Namban tsuba commonly have profuse gold decoration, either as nunome-
zogan or fire gilding. Soten tsuba are characterised by selective
and delicate inlays of gold, silver, copper and shakudo.

Soten tsuba do not demonstrate the decorartive mimi, seppa-dai and
ryo-hitsu which characterise Namban tsuba. Signatures, although
admittedly usually gimei, feature frequently on Soten tsuba and
almost never in the Namban group.

The design on Soten tsuba is themed, being is representative of
specific characters or incidents, while that on Namban tsuba is
purely decorative.

No, I personally know of no relationship between the two groups.

Regards, John L.


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Elliott" <elliott@...> wrote:
>
> First, I appreciate all the comments that were made in reference to
my
> question about 'cast' tsuba. And all the discussion about Namban
leads
> me to my next question for the group......
>
> What is the relationship between Nanban Tsuba and Soten Tsuba?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Elliott
>

messages.subject: Soten & Namban
messages.msgSnippet: First, I appreciate all the comments that were made in reference to my question about cast tsuba. And all the discussion about Namban leads me to my next
messages.messageBody:
First, I appreciate all the comments that were made in reference to my
question about 'cast' tsuba. And all the discussion about Namban leads
me to my next question for the group......

What is the relationship between Nanban Tsuba and Soten Tsuba?

Thanks,

Elliott
